title: 113_s743
content:
The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" authorizes the collection of sales and use taxes. The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" authorizes Member States under the Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement to require sellers to collect and remit sales taxes for remote sales, as long as changes to the agreement comply with simplification requirements. States can enforce this authority 180 days after the enactment of the Act. A State can exercise authority under the "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" 180 days after the enactment of the Act, as long as changes to the Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement comply with simplification requirements. Non-Member States can also require sellers to collect and remit sales taxes for remote sales. A State can exercise authority under the "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" 180 days after enactment, as long as it complies with simplification requirements. Non-Member States can also require sellers to collect and remit sales taxes for remote sales, starting at least 6 months after adopting the minimum simplification requirements. The State can exercise authority under the "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" 180 days after enactment, as long as it complies with simplification requirements for specified taxes and products/services. The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" allows the State to enforce tax authority after 180 days, following minimum simplification requirements for specified taxes and products/services. This includes appointing a single entity for all tax administration and return processing. The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" requires a single entity in the State to handle all sales and use tax administration, return processing, and audits for remote sales. The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" mandates a single sales and use tax return for remote sellers to be filed with the designated tax administration entity in the State. Remote sellers cannot be required to file returns more frequently than nonremote sellers or face additional tax collection requirements compared to nonremote sellers under this Act. The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" requires remote sellers to file a single sales and use tax return with the State tax administration entity. Remote sellers must have the same tax collection requirements as nonremote sellers and a uniform tax base among State and local jurisdictions. The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" mandates uniform sales and use tax bases among State and local jurisdictions, sourcing remote sales in compliance with set definitions, and providing information on taxability of products and services, exemptions, rates, and software for remote sellers. The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" requires uniform sales and use tax bases, sourcing remote sales, providing information on taxability, exemptions, rates, and software for remote sellers. The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" requires certified software providers to offer software capable of calculating and filing sales and use taxes in all qualified states, relieving remote sellers from liability for incorrect collection. The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" requires certified software providers to offer software for calculating and filing sales and use taxes in all qualified states, relieving remote sellers and software providers from liability for incorrect tax collection. The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" requires certified software providers to offer software for calculating and filing sales and use taxes in all qualified states, relieving them from liability for incorrect tax collection. This includes protection for remote sellers and software providers from penalties or interest due to misleading information. The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" relieves remote sellers and certified software providers from liability for incorrect tax collection due to misleading information provided by the State. It also requires a 90-day notice of rate changes by the State or any locality. The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" provides remote sellers and certified software providers with 90 days notice of a rate change by the State or any locality. Sellers are relieved from liability for collecting sales and use taxes at the previous rate if the required notice is not provided. The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" allows States to require remote sellers to collect sales and use taxes only if their total remote sales exceed $1,000,000 in the previous year. Gross annual receipts from remote sales of related persons can be aggregated to meet the threshold. For the purposes of determining if the threshold is met, gross annual receipts from remote sales of related persons can be aggregated if they are related within the meaning of specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code or if their ownership relationships were designed to avoid these rules. SEC. 3. LIMITATIONS. The Act does not subject sellers to various taxes other than sales and use taxes, does not affect tax application, and does not change state authority on taxes. It does not create nexus or change nexus standards between a person and a state. Sellers can still choose their own certified software provider. The Act does not alter nexus standards between a person and a state. Sellers can choose their own certified software provider without restrictions on licensing or regulatory requirements. The Act does not impose new taxes or regulations on intrastate businesses. It only applies to remote sales and does not affect interstate commerce matters. The Act encourages states to impose sales and use taxes on products or services not previously taxed. It applies only to remote sales and does not affect intrastate sales or the Mobile Telecommunications Sourcing Act. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS AND SPECIAL RULES. In this Act, a certified software provider is defined as a person who provides software to remote sellers for tax compliance and is certified by a State. The terms "locality" and "local" refer to any political subdivision of a State. A Member State is defined as a state under the Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement. In this Act, "locality" and "local" refer to any political subdivision of a State. A Member State is a state under the Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement, excluding associate members. The term "person" includes various legal entities and governments. A "remote sale" refers to a sale conducted from a distance. (4) Person.--Refers to individuals, trusts, estates, partnerships, corporations, and governments.
(5) Remote sale.--A sale into a State where the seller is not required to pay sales taxes unless specified by this Act.
(6) Remote seller.--A person making remote sales in the State.
(7) Sourced.--Used for State authority purposes. A remote seller is defined as a person making remote sales in the State. The sourcing of a remote sale is determined by the location where the product or service is received by the purchaser, based on delivery instructions provided by the purchaser. If no delivery location is specified, the sale is sourced to the customer's known address. The sourcing of a remote sale is determined by the delivery instructions provided by the purchaser. If no delivery location is specified, the sale is sourced to the customer's address known to the seller or obtained during the transaction. If the address is unknown and a billing address cannot be obtained, the sale is sourced to the seller's address. The sourcing of a remote sale is determined by the delivery instructions provided by the purchaser. If no delivery location is specified, the sale is sourced to the customer's address known to the seller or obtained during the transaction. If an address is unknown and a billing address cannot be obtained, the remote sale is sourced to the address of the seller from which the sale was made. States granted authority under section 2(a) must comply with the sourcing provisions of the Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement. The term "Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement" refers to a multi-state agreement adopted in 2002 and amended periodically. It applies to states, territories, tribal organizations, and certain jurisdictions for sales and use tax purposes. SEC. 5. SEVERABILITY. If any provision of this Act is deemed unconstitutional, the rest of the Act remains unaffected. SEC. 6. PREEMPTION. This Act does not override any powers held by State or local jurisdictions. The Act was passed by the Senate on May 6, 2013, as attested by Nancy Erickson, Secretary.
